temperature.title: Temperature
temperature.content:
Most relevant species of Campylobacter can grow at a temperature between 30°C and 42°C, although their optimal range is 37-42°C. Even if they cannot grow below 30°C, they can survive at lower temperature, including refrigeration ones, such as -4°C.
Campylobacter are very sensitive to heat. For example, 90% of Campylobacter bacteria mixed in minced meat will be inactivated in less than 9 minutes at 51°C, in 4.85 min at 53°C and in 0.79 min at 57°C

oxygen.title: Oxygen
oxygen.content: Campylobacter are “microaerophilic” organisms, meaning that they require oxygen, but at a lower concentration (3-15%) than the one found in the atmosphere (21%) and an elevated concentration of carbon dioxide (10% CO2).

ph.title: pH
ph.content: Campylobacter cannot survive below a pH of 4.9 and above pH 9.0 and can grow optimally at pH 6.5–7.5.

humidity.title: Water
humidity.content: Campylobacter can grow with a water activity (aw) > 0.987, thus is very susceptible to dry environment.

salinity.title: Salinity
salinity.content: Campylobacter has a low tolerance to salt, and it cannot grow with sodium chloride concentrations above 2.0%, with optimal growth at 0.5%. These concentrations are well below the ones used in those foods where salt is used as preservative.
